docs.lead_paragraph: A former majority owner of the Cincinnati Reds, Mr. Lindner was chairman of a holding company that grew to $17 billion in assets and employed nearly 70,000 people.

headline.seo: Carl H. Lindner Jr., Founder of American Financial, Dies at 92
headline.main: Carl H. Lindner Jr., Founder of American Financial, Dies at 92
headline.print_headline: Carl H. Lindner Jr., 92, Cincinnati Investor

docs.abstract: Carl H Lindner Jr, former majority owner of the Cincinnati Reds who used his experience running the family dairy store to build a business empire, dies at age 92.
docs.snippet: A former majority owner of the Cincinnati Reds, Mr. Lindner was chairman of a holding company that grew to $17 billion in assets and employed nearly 70,000 people.

docs.lead_paragraph: Declaring certain requirements obsolete or burdensome, the Obama administration proposed changes it said would save health care providers about $1.1 billion annually.

headline.seo: Obama Administration Seeks to Roll Back Hospital Rules
headline.main: U.S. Moves to Cut Back Regulations on Hospitals
headline.print_headline: U.S. Moves To Cut Back Regulations On Hospitals

docs.abstract: Obama administration moves to roll back numerous rules that apply to hospitals and other health care providers after concluding that standards are obsolete or overly burdensome to industry.
docs.snippet: Declaring certain requirements obsolete or burdensome, the Obama administration proposed changes it said would save health care providers about $1.1 billion annually.

headline.main: Views of the '99 Percent': Corporate Power Is Up While Living Standards are Down

docs.abstract: Americans who identify with Occupy Wall Street say income inequality, eroding standards of living and corporate greed drive their support.
docs.snippet: Americans who identify with Occupy Wall Street say income inequality, eroding standards of living and corporate greed drive their support.

docs.lead_paragraph: Offshoots of the Occupy Wall Street movement have spread across the United States with organized protests coming to life in dozens of cities throughout the country. But are the demonstrations resonating with the general public?

docs.lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs Reports $428 Million Loss  |  Goldman Sachs, weighed down by problems in its private equity portfolio and the broader global economic woes, reported a loss of $428 million, only the second quarterly loss since the investment bank went public in 1999.

headline.main: Behind the Class Act, a Numbers Game

docs.abstract: Why did the administration back away from the first government-run insurance program for long-term care? "We can make it work," said the actuary formerly in charge of developing the plan.
